answers.explanation: When differentiating between a choroidal nevus and choroidal melanoma, follow the mnemonic ‘To Find Small Ocular Melanoma Using Helpful Hints’ (TFSOMUHH) proposed by Shields et al.: thickness (>2mm), fluid (subretinal), symptoms (floaters, flashes), orange pigmentation, margin (< 3mm of disc), ultrasonographic hollowness and halo (absence). Drusen overlying choroidal nevi is not uncommon. Because the lesion thickness appears to be <2mm, no subretinal fluid is detected, the patient is asymptomatic, lesion margins are >3mm from the disc, and an orange pigmentation is not seen on fundoscopy, the lesion is likely benign.

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text:
What is the main abnormality seen on the OCT?

![](/content/media/retina-37-3.webp)

answers.explanation:
Choroidal nevi can exhibit different patterns on OCT.  In this case, the choroidal nevus has a hyper-reflective anterior border (yellow box) with thinning of the choriocapillaris. It is hypothesized that the hyper-reflectivity is secondary to the orientation of nevus cells and effacement of the overlying choriocapillaris. While this may occur around the entire nevus, the anterior cells cast a dark shadow (red arrow) that obscures this effect below. Also note that the overlying retina and Bruch’s membrane appears preserved in our case. There is no sub-retinal fluid and drusen seen on OCT.  

![](/content/media/retina-37-4.webp)

To properly evaluate a choroidal nevus on OCT, it is best to utilise enhanced depth imaging (EDI) OCT, which can allow for precise measurement of tumor thickness. For further information on this topic, please refer to the following articles:

References

Shah SU, Kaliki S, Shields CL, Ferenczy SR, Harmon SA, Shields JA. Enhanced depth imaging optical coherence tomography of choroidal nevus in 104 cases. Ophthalmology. 2012 May 1;119(5):1066-72.

Jonna G, Daniels AB. Enhanced depth imaging OCT of ultrasonographically flat choroidal nevi demonstrates 5 distinct patterns. Ophthalmology Retina. 2019 Mar 1;3(3):270-7.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: What is the most reasonable management plan for the patient?

answers.answerText: D. Routine follow-up with or without fundus photo and OCT
answers.explanation:
Depending on size and clinical suspicion of choroidal nevus, fundus photography, OCT and A/Bscan to measure for elevation may be performed. Large base diameter >4-5mm or those close to posterior pole may warrant frequent follow up at 6month initially to ensure no progression. A study by Shields et al. analyzed 2514 cases of choroidal nevi. Transformation into melanoma occurred in 2%, 9%, 13% of nevi within 1, 5, and 10 years, respectively. Therefore it is recommended to perform routine fundus examination and OCT imaging in these patients. Intravitreal anti-VEGF and intraocular corticosteroids are not recommended as a treatment for choroidal nevus.

References

Shields CL, Furuta M, Berman EL, et al. Choroidal nevus transformation into melanoma: analysis of 2514 consecutive cases. Arch Ophthalmol. 2009;127(8):981-987. doi:10.1001/archophthalmol.2009.151
